question: Question_05_(a)
statement: State what is means for a set \emph{A} to be denumerable.
sols:
A set \emph{A} is denumerable if it is in bijective correspondence with
the natural numbers. That is, it is denumerable if and only if there
exists a bijective function

\[\displaystyle
f: A \to \mathbb{N}\]

\textbf{Note:} Mathematicians think of this function as a
\emph{counting} of all the elements of the set \emph{A}. Given a
counting, that is such a bijection $f$ the \emph{first} element of the set
\emph{A} is the one that is mapped to 1 by the function, the
\emph{second} element is the one mapped to 2 and so on. Observe that we
need to require the function to be bijective to guarantee that all the
elements are counted and are counted in a unique way (we don't want to
have two elements mapped to the same natural number).
hints:
The word ``denumerable'' suggests natural numbers. Denumerable is
another word for \emph{countably infinite}.
